title: Residents across the UAE prepare to travel over Eid holidays
text:
GCC, Indian tourists to head to Dubai during Eid 
Wednesday, Jul 15, 2015 
Abu Dhabi: With Eid Al Fitr just around the corner, several residents are already getting a head start on the holidays. 
Residents in the country are using the opportunity to travel home to visit friends and family, while others are looking to escape the soaring temperatures. 
Continuing to keep her annual Eid traditions alive, Zain Masri, 23, marketing manager, told Gulf News that she is going back home for a family reunion. “My destination is Jordan, like every year. I am going there so I can spend some time with family and enjoy some authentic and delicious homemade food,” Zain said.
Zain's favourite Eid holiday was last year’s in Jordan as it was the first time she was meeting her extended family for years, which she said was a fun-filled gathering that revived heartfelt childhood memories. “Eid is also in July this year, which is a hot period in the UAE, so I am glad that I will be escaping some of the summer heat,” she added.
Yomna Abdul Rahim, 23, field engineer, also told Gulf News that home captures the true Eid spirit. “Being home feels different. It will never be the same without celebrating it with your family and friends,” she said. 
At times when Yomna is unable to travel to Egypt, her family celebrates the holiday in Abu Dhabi instead. 
“Being with family during Eid is one of our culture’s key traditions,” she added. 
While some residents choose to travel back to their countries during Eid, others find it more convenient to spend the holiday with their loved ones here. 
As the majority of her family members and friends are based in the country, Dima Salame, 23, senior account executive, continues to spend Eid here in the UAE every year, a place she calls home. 
Particularly looking forward to this one, Dima said, “Last year was exceptional as it was a full house. However, my fiance is now a part of our family, whom we will be celebrating Eid with for the first time.” 
Noushad Aziz, Manager at Land of Holidays Travel Agency, said that the upcoming Eid holidays have seen an “expatriate rush and it will be busy over the Eid holidays, with many families travelling home to be with friends and family”. 
“This year again Eid coincides with the summer holidays, so people travelling combine the two together. Many people sent their families home before Eid, with the children travelling once schools closed, so they will now join the rest of the family during this period.” 
Bilal Khalil, Sales Manager at Leading Hotels of the World, said that Europe was also proving to be a popular destination. “You have what I call the comfort zones, London, Paris, Geneva, and Munich. These destinations have always been popular and continue to be so during this holiday period.” 
“I would also say that people are becoming more adventurous and open to trying new and different places now as well. We are getting bookings to places like Santorini, Marbella, and Tenerife. A few years ago you wouldn’t really hear much about people from this area travelling to Tenerife,” he added. 
Khalil also mentioned that while people were still travelling to other Middle Eastern destinations such as Egypt and Jordan, the “numbers are not as high due to some of the political turmoil in the region”. 
Maisoon Mubarak and Heidi Pullyard are trainees at Gulf News
